title: Height-Limit for Shared Alleyway Marker
vignette: Residents install a horizontal beam over their private alley so they can move items there on the upcoming community rest day. After mounting it, they notice the beam is far above the city's maximum signage height. Should they lower it or leave it?

options.text: Lower the beam; current placement violates city code.
Leave it; height doesn't matter if walls are sturdy.

title: Absent Traveler in Shared-Courtyard Agreement
vignette: Ten families pooled resources to create a weekend-use agreement for their common yard, but one member is out of town and forgot to contribute. Night falls before he returns. May the others rely on a phone call in which he waives his usage rights, or is the agreement invalid until he personally joins?

options.text: Everyone may use the space if the traveler relinquishes his rights.
No one may use the space until a valid agreement includes all residents.

title: Community Pass Eaten by Animals
vignette: Ruth placed a food token at the city edge to extend her walking zone on the rest day. Before sundown, dogs ate the food, but she only discovers this later.

options.text: She may walk the extended distance since the pass existed at the deadline.
Her pass is void, so she must stay within the regular limit.

title: One Perimeter Pass for a Two-Day Holiday?
vignette: A Thursday-Friday public holiday restricts walking beyond a two-kilometer boundary. Can a single perimeter pass, placed on Wednesday, authorize the same extended walk on both days, or must a fresh pass be set for Friday?

options.text: Yes, prepare one pass for the entire span.
No, each day requires its own pass.

title: Using a Tethered Animal as a Wall
vignette: Campers need a fourth wall for their pop-up booth and tie a calm camel in place to form that side. Is a living creature a reliable barrier, or must the wall be fixed and inert?

options.text: Permissible; any sturdy barrier counts.
Not acceptable since it might wander.

title: Community Pass Placed Just Beyond the Boundary
vignette: Measuring after sunset reveals the food token was a few feet past the 2-kilometer limit.

options.text: Rely on the initial measurement; the intent was valid.
The pass fails; stay within the standard boundary.

title: Late Placement of a Perimeter Pass
vignette: A hiking group intended to leave a perimeter pass before sunset but only dropped the food parcel after dark. Does the pass take effect because they planned ahead, or is any late placement invalid?

options.text: Count it; they intended before nightfall.
Too late; traveling farther is prohibited.

title: Community Pass Made with Spoiled Food
vignette: The only food available for a community pass was already moldy. They used it anyway.

options.text: It works so long as an animal would still eat it.
Spoiled food cannot establish a valid community pass.

title: Window vs. Doorway in Shared-Space Permit
vignette: Two neighboring flats have only a small window between themâ€”no door. They want to combine spaces for moving items during a rest day. Is the window enough, or is a walk-through doorway required?

options.text: Yes, a window connection suffices.
No, only a full doorway allows merging.

title: Linking Rooftops of Unequal Height
vignette: Adjacent apartment roofs differ in height. Residents want to treat them as one zone when relaxing outside. If the level difference is modest, can they combine, or does any step-up break the shared status?

options.text: They combine if the height difference is small.
Different heights keep them separate.

title: Guardian Setting a Community Pass for a Child
vignette: A father places a food token for his young son so the boy can walk farther on the rest day.

options.text: Valid; a guardian may act on behalf of minors.
Invalid; only adults can establish their own community pass.

title: Alley Open on One Side
vignette: An alley bordered by houses on three sides opens directly to a field. Is a side-post enough to permit shared use?

options.text: Yes, a single side-post makes it a proper shared alley.
No, such an open alley cannot be a shared space.

title: Village and Town Merge Through New Housing
vignette: New houses now form a continuous row from a village to the nearby town. For walking-limit rules, do the two settlements merge into one, or does the village keep its separate boundary?

options.text: Yes, treat them as one community.
No, each retains its own boundary.

title: Community Pass Stored in a Cracked Jar
vignette: The food token was placed in a jug that later shattered but still partly holds the food.

options.text: It's fine; the container still functions.
No, an intact vessel is required.

title: Village Absorbed by a Growing City
vignette: New houses now link a small village to the nearby town. Do their walking-limit boundaries merge?

options.text: Yes, treat them as one community.
No, the village retains its own boundary.
